feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Flood Watch issued August 9 at 10:06PM CDT until August 10 at 7:00AM CDT by NWS Amarillo TX
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of the Panhandle of Oklahoma, including the following counties, Cimarron and Texas and the Panhandle of Texas, including the following counties, Dallam, Hansford, Hartley, Hutchinson, Moore, Oldham and Sherman.
* WHEN...Until 7 AM CDT Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Thunderstorms are expected late this afternoon through Saturday morning that could produce heavy rainfall rates upwards of 2 inches per hour. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cimarron; Texas; Dallam; Sherman; Hansford; Hartley; Moore; Hutchinson; Oldham

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 AM CDT SATURDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 9 at 10:05PM CDT by NWS Austin/San Antonio TX
entry.summary:
At 1005 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 9 miles north of Stockdale, moving west at 15 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and half inch hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor damage to outdoor objects is possible.
Locations impacted include... Seguin, Cibolo, Stockdale, La Vernia, New Berlin, Pandora, Zuehl, Sutherland Springs, and Zipp.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 9 at 10:37PM EDT until August 10 at 1:45AM EDT by NWS Raleigh NC
entry.summary:
FFWRAH
The National Weather Service in Raleigh has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Western and Central Guilford County in central North Carolina...
* Until 145 AM EDT.
* At 1037 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1 and locally 3 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Greensboro, High Point, Summerfield, Jamestown, Oak Hollow Marina, Lake Brandt and Lake Jeanette Marina.

cap:parameter.value: NWS: FLASH FLOOD WARNING this area til 1:45 AM EDT. Avoid flooded areas.

National Weather Service: A FLASH FLOOD WARNING is in effect for this area until 1:45 AM EDT. This is a dangerous and life-threatening situation. Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 9 at 7:36PM MDT until August 9 at 10:00PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
At 736 PM MDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain filling in over the southern half of the Hermits Peak and Calf Canyon Burn Scar, just west of Sapello, El Porvenir and Mineral Hill. Between 0.5 and 1 inch of rain has fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1 inch are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
Excessive rainfall over the burn scar will impact the Tecolote Creek and Gallinas River drainage areas. The debris flow can consist of rock, mud, vegetation and other loose materials.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding in and around the Hermits Peak and Calf Canyon Burn Scar.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of areas in and around the Hermits Peak and Calf Canyon Burn Scar.
Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... El Porvenir, Montezuma, Sapello, Tierra Monte, Gallinas, Mineral Hill, Rociada, Manuelitas and San Geronimo.
This includes the following highways... State Road 94 between Mile Markers 1 and 9. State Road 518 between Mile Markers 10 and 16. State Road 283 between Mile Markers 7 and 12...and near Mile Marker 14. State Road 276 between Mile Markers 0 and 5. State Road 266 between Mile Markers 0 and 6. State Road 65 between Mile Markers 1 and 14. State Road 105 between Mile Markers 0 and 6.
This includes the following recreation areas... E.V. Long Campground and El Porvenir Campground.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 9 at 9:15PM EDT until August 13 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Georgia...
Altamaha River At Everett City affecting McIntosh, Wayne and Glynn Counties.
Altamaha River At Doctortown affecting Long and Wayne Counties.
Satilla River At Atkinson affecting Brantley County.
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Georgia...
Satilla River At Waycross affecting Pierce and Ware Counties.

* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Altamaha River at Everett City.
* WHEN...Until Tuesday evening.
* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, Agricultural and timber lands near the river are flooded. At 13.0 feet, Water begins to encroach upon Altamaha Regional Park in Glynn County. This includes Altamaha Park Road, Betty Lott Lane and Bee Tree Island Road. In McIntosh County, Barrington Park at the end of Harper Lake Road begins to flood. Blue Reach Road also begins to flood near the Long County line. At 14.0 feet, Portions of Altamaha Regional Park become inundated, including the park campground, boat ramps and parking lots. Bee Tree Island Road is flooded and closed. The end of Betty Lott Lane is flooded and homes become cut off. At 15.0 feet, In Glynn County, the majority of Altamaha Regional Park becomes inundated, including water flowing across sections of Altamaha Park Road and Pennick Road. The Altamaha Regional Park is subject to closure at this level. Homes in the vicinity of the park are cut off by flood waters at this level, but elevated structures are not flooded. In McIntosh County, much of Barrington Park is underwater. Plum Orchard Road begins to flood.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:45 PM EDT Friday the stage was 14.1 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 14.4 feet early tomorrow afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage early Tuesday afternoon. - Flood stage is 13.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 9 at 6:03PM PDT by NWS Pendleton OR
entry.summary: Showers and thunderstorms have developed this afternoon across the Washington Cascade crests. These storms have produced abundant lighting and heavy downpours at times, with as much as an inch an hour reported near Stevens Pass. While these storms are largely expected to remain over the wilderness, those outdoors should consider finding shelter until storms dissipate. Those with friends or loved ones hiking or camping in the area should reach out if possible, as these storms could produce minor flooding in canyons or deep valleys, combined with the threat of lightning and even small hail.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Upper Slopes of the Eastern Washington Cascades Crest

* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Mary's River at Macclenny.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, Minor flooding of low lying areas and timber lands including some properties along St. Mary's River Bluff Road and the Cypress Landing Resort on the Georgia side. At 14.0 feet, Flooding of bottomlands along the river and some lower access roads including the lower half of St. Mary's River Bluff Road which cuts off 15 to 20 homes on the Georgia side. At 15.0 feet, Flooding begins to impact the lower end of Steel Bridge Road on the Florida side and cuts off access to the river gage as well as access to several homes. At 16.0 feet, Access roads on both sides of the river in Florida and Georgia are flooded, including the entire low lying stretch of St. Mary's River Bluff Road on the Georgia side which cuts off 40 to 50 homes. On the Florida side, the lower end of St. Mary's Cove Road past the public boat ramp becomes flooded and cuts off access to 20 to 30 homes. The Stokes Road Bridge over the river is generally closed due to high water. At 17.0 feet, High water on the river reaches the bottom of the Stokes Road Bridge.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 9 at 2:57PM AKDT until August 10 at 12:45PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
Flooding is ongoing, however as of this afternoon water levels are beginning to fall on the Skwentna River and are cresting on the Yentna River near Lake Creek.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Lake Creek, Yentna and Skwentna Rivers.
* WHEN...Until 1245 PM AKDT Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 240 PM AKDT this afternoon, water levels are beginning to fall on the Skwentna River and are cresting on the Yentna River near Lake Creek. Water is overbank along the Yentna River with reports of widespread flooding of low lying areas and flooding of several lodges and cabins along the Yentna River and Lake Creek.
Another round of moderate rainfall is expected to begin Saturday morning through Sunday afternoon with an additional 1 to 2 inches possible. River levels are expected to slowly fall through the weekend but remain high due to this additional rainfall.
Large amounts of debris has been reported moving down the Yentna River.
- Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 9 at 6:38PM EDT until August 10 at 6:45AM EDT by NWS Charleston SC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...A portion of southeast South Carolina, including the following counties, Berkeley, Charleston, Colleton and Dorchester.
* WHEN...Until 645 AM EDT Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Numerous roads remain closed due to flooding. Streams continue to rise due to excess runoff from earlier rainfall. Additional rains early tonight, which are mainly across Berkeley will only exacerbate the flooding.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 630 PM EDT, Flooding continues and is worsening along several creeks and streams across portions of Dorchester and Berkeley Counties. Significant flooding is ongoing across Jedburg, Ridgeville, Moncks Corner, and Bonneau areas. Scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms will continue to impact the area early tonight, mainly across Berkeley County. These storms could result in an additional 1 to 2 inches of rainfall. This rainfall may lead to new flooding rapidly. - Water levels along French Quarter Creek near Huger in Berkeley County remain in the major flood category and a number of homes are flooded along the creek. This includes areas along French Quarter Creek Road.
Water levels at Ireland Creek at Walterboro are just below the moderate flood stage and may remain there through tonight. Water will continue to impact some businesses and home along Ivanhoe Road between Forest Hills Road and Lands End Road.
Water levels along the Ashley River are slowly rising and may begin to flood nearby neighborhoods including the Ashborough neighborhood.
Church Creek near West Ashley will remain just below flood stage through the night.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued August 9 at 2:09PM AKDT until August 11 at 10:00PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...The following areas, eastern Kenai Peninsula and western Prince William Sound. This includes the cities of Seward, Moose Pass, and Whittier.
* WHEN...From Saturday morning through Sunday evening.
* IMPACTS...Already saturated soils may lead to excessive runoff and result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Area creeks and streams are running high and could flood with more heavy rain. Landslides may be possible in areas of steep terrain.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - A period of rain is forecast for the eastern Kenai Peninsula and western Prince William Sound beginning Saturday morning and continuing through Sunday night. There is moderate confidence for total rainfall amounts of up to 2 inches for Seward, up to an inch for Moose Pass, and 1 to 3 inches for Whittier, with higher amounts likely in higher terrain. Rain may be heavy at times resulting in excessive runoff on already saturated soils.
- Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
- Stay away from steep barren hillsides due to the landslide danger.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued August 9 at 2:58PM PDT until August 10 at 12:00AM PDT by NWS Seattle WA
entry.summary:
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 658 West Slopes of the North Cascades Generally above 1500 Feet.
* THUNDERSTORMS...Scattered thunderstorms are expected over the North Cascades with LAL of 3 during the afternoon and evening hours.
* OUTFLOW WINDS...Gusty and erratic winds are possible in the vicinity of any thunderstorms that develop.
* IMPACTS...Scattered lightning in dry fuels can cause multiple fire starts. Thunderstorms can also bring sudden sharp wind shifts on existing fires, causing rapid changes in a fire's rate of spread and direction of spread. Thunderstorm outflow winds can be a threat for several hours following the start of a new lightning-caused fire. If a fire were to begin, air quality may diminish in the surrounding area.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 9 at 4:06PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
entry.summary:
AQAHGX
The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has issued an Ozone Action Day for the Houston, Galveston, and Brazoria area for Saturday, August 10, 2024.
Atmospheric conditions are expected to be favorable for producing high levels of ozone pollution in the Houston, Galveston, and surrounding areas on Saturday. You can help prevent ozone pollution by sharing a ride, walking, riding a bicycle, taking your lunch to work, avoiding drive through lanes, conserving energy and keeping your vehicle properly tuned.
For more information on ozone: Ozone: The Facts www.tceq.texas.gov/airquality/monops/ozonefacts.html EPA AirNow: www.airnow.gov/?city=Houston&state=TX&country=USA Take Care of Texas: www.takecareoftexas.org/conservation-tips/keep-our-air-clean

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 9 at 1:17PM PDT by NWS Portland OR
entry.summary:
The Oregon Department of Environmental Quality and the Lane Regional Air Protection Agency have continued an Air Quality Advisory, which is in effect until 1 PM PDT Monday.
An Air Quality Advisory for smoke remains in effect. Wildfires burning in the region combined with forecasted conditions will cause air quality to reach unhealthy levels at times through at least 1 PM PDT Monday.
Pollutants in smoke can cause burning eyes, runny nose, aggravate heart and lung diseases, and aggravate other serious health problems. Limit outdoor activities and keep children indoors if it is smoky. Please follow medical advice if you have a heart or lung condition.
More information about air quality can be found at: www.oregon.gov/DEQ www.lrapa.org

An Air Quality Advisory for smoke remains in effect. Wildfires burning in the region combined with forecasted conditions will cause air quality to reach unhealthy levels at times through at least 1 PM PDT Monday.
Pollutants in smoke can cause burning eyes, runny nose, aggravate heart and lung diseases, and aggravate other serious health problems. Limit outdoor activities and keep children indoors if it is smoky. Please follow medical advice if you have a heart or lung condition.
More information about air quality can be found at: www.oregon.gov/DEQ www.lrapa.org
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lane County Cascade Foothills; Cascades of Lane County

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 1 PM PDT MONDAY

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 9 at 12:38PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
Oregon Department of Environmental Quality has issued an Air Pollution Advisory...in effect until at least 3 PM PDT on Monday, August 12.
The Oregon Department of Environmental Quality issued an air quality advisory for Lake, Klamath, and central amd eastern Douglas counties due to wildfires burning in the region. The DEQ also expects intermittent smoke in Jackson and Josephine counties through this period due to smoke from surrounding fires.
The wildfire smoke combined with forecast conditions will cause air quality levels to fluctuate and could be at unhealthy levels.
Smoke levels can change rapidly depending on the weather and planned burn operations. Smoke can irritate the eyes and lungs and worsen some medical conditions. People most at risk include infants and young children, people with heart or lung disease, older adults and pregnant people.
People can take the following precautions to protect their health:
- Follow local burn restrictions to prevent deteriorating air quality. - Avoid strenuous outdoor activity during periods of poor air quality. - People with heart or lung problems and young children are especially vulnerable. These people should stay indoors while smoke levels are high. - Use certified High Efficiency Particulate Air (HEPA) filters in indoor heating, ventilation, cooling and air purification systems. - Avoid using wood-burning stoves and other sources of indoor smoke if possible.
For additional information...please visit the web site at https://oregonsmoke.org

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued August 9 at 11:49AM PDT until August 10 at 12:00AM PDT by NWS Spokane WA
entry.summary:
...ABUNDANT LIGHTNING IN CASCADES THIS AFTERNOON AND EVENING...
Showers and thunderstorms will expand in coverage over the Cascades this afternoon with abundant lightning into the evening hours. A mix of wet and dry thunderstorms is expected with enough lightning to occur to overcome the extinguishing effects of rain. This will especially be so for lightning strikes outside of cores of thunderstorms.
* Affected Area: Fire Weather Zone 696 East Washington Central Cascades (Zone 696), Fire Weather Zone 697 East Portion of North Cascades National Park/Lake Chelan National Recreation Area (Zone 697), Fire Weather Zone 698 East Washington North Cascades (Zone 698), Fire Weather Zone 703 Okanogan Valley (Zone 703), Fire Weather Zone 704 Methow Valley (Zone 704) and Fire Weather Zone 705 Foothills of Central Washington Cascades (Zone 705).
* Thunderstorms: Abundant lightning resulting in frequent cloud to ground lightning strikes.
* Outflow Winds: Gusty and erratic outflow winds of up to 40 mph will be possible.
* Impacts: Lightning may result in new fire starts. Gusty outflow winds will be capable of rapid fire spread and causing erratic wind directions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: East Washington Central Cascades; East Portion of North Cascades National Park / Lake Chelan National Recreation Area; East Washington North Cascades; Okanogan Valley; Methow Valley; Central Washington Cascade Foothills

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 9 at 2:34PM EDT until August 10 at 10:00AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Minor flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Rocky River in Cabarrus County, North Carolina.
* WHEN...Until 1000 AM EDT Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Common, deeper flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to area streams is ongoing with lesser impacts to vulnerable property. Expect extensive flooding of farmland, parks, greenways, boat-access areas, and golf courses. Inundation may be several feet deep. Several low-water crossings, roads, and bridges may be flooded and impassible, with deeper flows over roadways possible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 229 PM EDT, Storm-total rainfall of 4-6 inches from Tropical Cyclone Debby resulted in significant rises along the Rocky River in Cabarrus County. The Rocky River crested late Thursday night and is now gradually receding. However, the river remains well above Minor Flood Stage with extensive impacts to low-lying areas adjacent to the river from Pharrs Mill to Georgeville to Midland. The Rocky River is not expected to fall below Minor Flood Stage until late Friday night and below Action/Advisory Stage until Saturday morning. Therefore, a Flood Warning will remain in effect through Saturday morning to allow the Rocky River to crest and recede below critical levels. However, conditions will gradually improve throughout the day today as flood waters gradually recede and the impacts will become confined to adjacent low- lying areas that typically flood.
- The following streamgauge is above Minor Flood Stage, resulting in Minor flooding along the Rocky River from Harrisburg to Georgeville...
ID: IBFN7 NAME: above Irish Buffalo Creek, 5 W Georgeville CURRENT STAGE: 21.69 feet ACTION/ADVISORY STAGE: 12.0 feet MINOR FLOOD STAGE: 16.5 feet MODERATE FLOOD STAGE: 26 feet CREST: 24.26 feet at 12:30am on August 9, 2024 TREND: Falling steadily.
ESTIMATED FORECAST and IMPACTS: The river will fall below Minor Flood Stage overnight Friday night, approximately between midnight and 4:00am early Saturday morning. The river is expected to fall below Action/Advisory Stage Saturday morning or early Saturday afternoon. Between 20 and 22 feet, flooding is occurring near and over the intersection of Mt Pleasant Rd and NC 200 with extensive flooding of farmland and other low-lying areas along NC 200. Floodwaters are approaching and possibly flooding NC 200 with backwater effects flooding Parks Lafferty Rd. As the river falls below 20 feet, impacts will decrease in severity, and the primary impacts will be mostly confined to adjacent farmland and wooded areas. Please obey all barricades that remain in place following the flood to allow engineers to assess road safety and make necessary repairs.
- The Rocky River is flooding areas near the following locations... Pharrs Mill, Georgeville, and Midland.
- Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 9 at 12:38PM EDT until August 10 at 1:30PM EDT by NWS Tallahassee FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Madison County Emergency Management continued to report gradually rising water levels in southeastern Madison County just south of Interstate 10 east of County Road 360, especially in the vicinity of I-10 and Exit 258 due to past heavy rainfall from Hurricane Debby.
* WHERE...Southeast Madison County in the Florida Big Bend
* WHEN...Until at least Saturday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Water levels are likely to continue to rise and gradually spread to areas south and east across the county as localized runoff continues. Numerous roads are flooded, along with a campground near Exit 258 being significantly impacted. Some roads are already or will soon become impassable.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1236 PM EDT, Flooding will likely persist into the weekend due to more than 12 inches of rain that occurred across the warning area from Hurricane Debby. With high groundwater levels, locations near small creeks, springs, or sinks in Southeast Madison County could be prone to flooding on relatively short notice. If you live in an area prone to flooding, take action to protect property. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Hopewell. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

For the Horse Creek...including Arcadia at SR 72...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Cypress Creek at SR 54 Worthington Gardens.

* IMPACTS...At 8.0 feet, Flooding begins at the recreation area on State Road 54.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:00 AM EDT Friday the stage was 9.4 feet. - Bankfull stage is 8.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 11:00 AM EDT Friday was 9.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall to 8.5 feet Monday morning. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 9.4 feet on 08/14/1978. - https://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 8 at 7:21AM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ
entry.summary:
AQAPSR
The Arizona Department of Environmental Quality (ADEQ) has extended an Ozone High Pollution Advisory for the Phoenix Metro Area through Friday.
This means that forecast weather conditions combined with existing ozone levels are expected to result in local maximum 8-hour ozone concentrations that pose a health risk. Adverse health effects increase as air quality deteriorates.
Ozone is an air contaminant which can cause breathing difficulties for children, older adults, as well as persons with respiratory problems. A decrease in physical activity is recommended.
You are urged to car pool, telecommute or use mass transit. The use of gasoline-powered equipment should be reduced or done late in the day.
For details on this High Pollution Advisory, visit the ADEQ internet site at www.azdeq.gov/forecast/phoenix or call 602-771-2300.

cap:parameter.value: OZONE HIGH POLLUTION ADVISORY FOR MARICOPA COUNTY INCLUDING THE PHOENIX METRO AREA THROUGH FRIDAY

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 8 at 9:05AM EDT until August 10 at 12:00PM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
entry.summary:
FFWILM
The National Weather Service in Wilmington has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Central Marlboro County in northeastern South Carolina...
* Until noon EDT Saturday.
* At 905 AM EDT, Crooked Creek at North Marlboro Street is beginning to come out of its banks at a gage level of about 19 feet. Modeling of water levels incorporating rainfall from Tropical Storm Debby, indicates the creek could rise another 4 to 6 feet by the 10th.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding resulting from runoff from recent rainfall.
SOURCE...Gauge reported and modeling.
IMPACT...Potentially life threatening flash flooding of along the creek of area streets.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Bennettsville.

National Weather Service: A FLASH FLOOD WARNING is in effect for this area until 4:00 PM UTC Sat. This is a dangerous and life-threatening situation. Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order.
